newsitem.title: UK: RUGBY UNION-CAMPESE POISED TO FACE WALES.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-CAMPESE POISED TO FACE WALES.

text.p: David Campese is ready to steal Jonathan Davies' thunder when the unbeaten Australians tackle Wales at Cardiff Arms Park on Sunday.
World record try scorer Campese and recalled fly-half Davies celebrated their 34th birthdays within 72 hours of each other last month.
Australian coach Greg Smith looks likely to follow Welsh counterpart Kevin Bowring by deciding that ability should always come before age.
If, as expected, Campese wins his 101st cap, it will be the first on British soil since 1992 when he scored a try against the same opponents on the same ground as Australia triumphed 23-6.

"Campo was sensational during our victory over Munster on Tuesday and he has made it very difficult for me to leave him out," said Smith, following a punishing two-hour training session in the Cardiff suburbs on Thursday.
"This current Australian team is performance-based, and once you start to ignore individual performance levels then you are really creating a standard which is not relevant to the professional game."
Campese became only the second player to reach 100 caps after French centre Philippe Sella when Australia overpowered Italy in Padova last month.

But so far he has been overlooked on the British leg of Australia's 13-match British tour, kicking his heels in frustration while Tim Horan, Jason Little and Joe Roff shared wing duties against Scotland and Ireland.
However, a three-quarter reshuffle, which may see Little or centre Daniel Herbert left out, should reopen the door for Campese when Smith announces the side on Friday.
"I am very happy to be part of the 21-man squad for this game," said Campese.

"We will just have to wait and see whether I am in the team or not, but it would be great to play in Cardiff again. The Arms Park is a great oval and I've got a lot of friends around this part of the world."
Campese could find himself wearing the unfamiliar No 14 jersey, switching from his traditional left-wing berth, if Thursday's training line-up has any significance.

"It would be unfortunate perhaps missing out on the chance to play opposite Ieuan Evans again, but Greg has got some good ideas which means different players appearing in different positions," Ca,pese said.

Wales are well down the list of Campese's try-scoring exploits, conceding just three against him as compared to Argentina (nine), New Zealand (eight), Scotland (six) and England (five). His tally currently stands at 64.
